sections.title: Income vs Expenses: The Foundation of Financial Health
sections.subtitle: Master the relationship between money in and money out

sections.title: Why This Matters
sections.content: Understanding the relationship between your income and expenses is crucial for building wealth and achieving financial stability. This simple concept forms the foundation of all personal finance decisions.

points.title: Active Income
points.description: Money earned from work - salary, wages, tips, freelance income. This requires your time and effort to generate.

points.title: Passive Income
points.description: Money earned with minimal ongoing effort - rental income, dividends, royalties. The goal is to build this over time.

points.title: Portfolio Income
points.description: Money from investments - capital gains, interest, dividends. This comes from your money working for you.

points.title: Fixed Expenses
points.description: Same amount each month - rent, insurance, loan payments. These are predictable and harder to change quickly.

points.title: Variable Expenses
points.description: Change each month - groceries, utilities, gas. These fluctuate but are still necessary.

points.title: Discretionary Expenses
points.description: Optional spending - dining out, entertainment, hobbies. These are the easiest to adjust when needed.

sections.title: The Golden Rule of Personal Finance
sections.content: Always spend less than you earn. The difference between your income and expenses is what you can save and invest for your future. This surplus is the foundation of wealth building.

sections.title: The Income-Expense Gap
sections.content: The gap between your income and expenses determines your financial trajectory. A positive gap (surplus) allows you to save and invest. A negative gap (deficit) leads to debt and financial stress. Your goal is to widen this gap over time by increasing income and optimizing expenses.

sections.title: Your Action Steps
steps: List all your income sources for the past month
Categorize your expenses into fixed, variable, and discretionary
Identify one expense you can reduce this month
Set a target savings rate (start with 10% if you're new to this)

sections.title: Pro Tip
sections.content: Aim to save at least 20% of your income. If that seems impossible now, start with 1% and increase it by 1% each month. The habit is more important than the amount when you're starting out.
